dialogue.raw_text: Fantastic. Tomorrow night. I'll pick you up at eight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Most likely it'll be our last date though, so just know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's very sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No it wasn't. Did you not hear what I said?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, no I was being... (pause; searching) ...there's no word for it. See you tomorrow night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ON T.V) In Our World.... in the 1800's...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The screen is all black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The black fades to ANGELO BADSMITH, a middle-aged African American man sitting before a fire in a green smoking jacket, holding a script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The screen reads: "The Industrial Revolution. Summer `07."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (ON T.V) ... came the greatest revolution of them all. (climactic music) The Industrial Revolution.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ON T.V) Written by famed screenwriter Rob Marlowe and read by Oscar winning Reader Angelo Badsmith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, I'm Angelo Badmsith. Come watch me read about the exciting events that took place during the Industrial Revolution. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) Also, I will tell you all about my personal misfortunes, such as my wife who cheated on me with a man named Perry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : His eyes are wide. The wheels in his head are spinning again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Mark jumps and runs to his kitchen table. He grabs a pen, pulls out a sheet of paper... and begins writing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rob Marlowe, your streak of success has finally come to an end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Mark writing furiously throughout the night, piling up page upon page. By the time the sun comes up Mark is exhausted, with barely the energy to keep his head up as he writes "the end" and places the final page on his large stack of finished pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark hustles through the parking lot, manuscript in hand. He reaches the door and then stops -- remembering something. Mark runs to the curb and throws his manuscript onto the dirty, filthy street. He gets down on his hands and knees and rubs his manuscript into the grime, making sure to get every page equally filthy. Satisfied, he organizes the pages into a neat pile and enters Lecture Films.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark walks the aisles of Lecture Films. People stop to stare at him. There is a whispered hubbub from the many cubicles and offices. Mark passes his old office, stopping to read the sign on the door: "14TH CENTURY -- CLOSED." Mark grimaces and keeps walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mark turns his head to see Shelley, standing down the hall, terrified, staring at Mark. Mark ignores her and keeps walking. Leaning against his door jamb, is Rob, smirking as Mark passes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark walks right up to the door that reads, "Head of Development -- Anthony James." Mark opens the door. Anthony is on the phone, his back to Mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anthony turns around to find Mark. His face becomes very, very scared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anthony is relieved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both stare at each other for a long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark pulls up a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark places his muddy, dirty, manuscript down on Anthony's desk. Anthony is scared to touch it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The excitement drains from Anthony's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anthony rolls his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anthony's eyes widen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark picks up the manuscript and opens the first page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anthony's mouth drops to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark smiles. Anthony picks up his phone and presses "intercom".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anthony hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The room is filled with people now, all of them hanging on every word Mark reads from his manuscript. Even Rob and Shelly lean against the back wall, their minds blown by the story Mark is telling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People around the room wipe tears from their eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The entire room bursts into applause. Not just normal applause, but massive, epic applause. Everyone crowds around Mark, hugging him, touching him, blown away by the magnanimity of the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark thinks it over for a moment and looks right at Rob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rob sneers. Everyone "aahs" and claps again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) He's gone crazy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come to beg for your old job back? Hey everybody, here's the loser who thought the Black Plague would make for an interesting film. Good luck, douche bag. Freaking loser.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're going to fire me any moment, I just know it. I'm really, really horrible at my job. I don't know anything about movies. I don't even like movies. I like sports. Head of development, what does that even mean? I'm not a smart person. Okay, talk to you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was the head of the studio. (PAUSE) I'm very scared that you're mad at me about the whole firing thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not mad at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh good, because I feel really bad about it. I mean, I would be horrible at your job too. I would be horrible at any job in this place. (PAUSE) I love sports.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you fired me, I was very depressed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And so I left this building and I just started walking. And I walked all the way out of town. And then I walked into the desert and I fell asleep under a tree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't do well with other people's life changing events.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And when I woke up I found this strange old chest sticking out of the ground. So I started digging. And I unearthed a very old and ancient box. Probably, oh... about... seven hundred years old. And inside the box... (holding up manuscript) ... was this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a never-before-heard historical event from the past.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When does it take place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The 1300's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you we're not interested in Black Plague movies here, Mark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This one isn't about the black plague. Well it isn't just about the black plague. Let me read you some of this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anthony, get excited about this. This is a brand new event from history that no one has ever heard before. It's a great human discovery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, but is there a movie there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The greatest movie Lecture Films has ever made.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Start reading.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the very first day of the fourteenth century, a momentous occasion occurred. It began as a day much like any other. The sun rose, the people awoke, workers began to work, babies began to cry. But all of that was interrupted when a giant flying space ship crashed down from the skies and landed in the heart of Babylon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want everyone in here now! We've got a BIG ONE.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Mark. Continue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As the smoke cleared, the door to the spaceship opened and inside, were hundreds of beautiful, half naked alien women.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And then the ninja army unleashed a giant fireball that brought the robot dinosaur to its knees, saving Mars, Earth and the Nude Amazonian Alien Women all in one sweeping motion. The earth was saved. Jebediah and Aleena were allowed to marry by alien king Xardon. It was to be the First Human-Nude Amazonian Alien Woman wedding, and no expenses would be spared. All of Babylon and Mars were invited to join in the celebrations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The wedding was held on a brisk summers day on Mars, with all of the survivors of the Great Ninja War and the Black Plague present. They feasted and danced and laughed and it was a joyous occasion. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) The moment the bride and groom kissed, King Xardon performed a mind-wipe on all of the humans, thereby erasing all knowledge of these events from their minds, and sent them back to Babylon. For seven hundred years these events would be forgotten by mankind until one day, a great writer by the name of Mark Bellison, would stumble upon them in the desert, after being fired by his shit boss Anthony and mocked by Rob and Shelly, two huge douche bags. Lecture Films Motion Picture Studios would go on to make the picture and it would be a big success, and Mark would become very wealthy and famous from it. The End.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mark, tell us what it's called.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Rob) The Black Plague.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mark and Jennifer sit at a candlelit table in the corner of a hip and fancy restaurant. Jennifer looks beautiful. Mark is on cloud nine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark smiles. They both sip their drinks and look at their menus. The waiter comes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waiter leaves. Mark and Jennifer stare at each other for a short beat. Something has changed between them and they can both feel it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jennifer is touched...but she doesn't reciprocate Mark's feelings. Jennifer moves on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Congratulations on selling your script today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. Thank you for having dinner with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone needs to eat. (PAUSE) And I enjoy your company.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm an extremely important waiter. (PAUSE) What can I get you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to know what it is, I just want to order the most expensive thing on the menu.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll have the duck. And I think you look like a little rat faced man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, I'll have those right up for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Things seem to be turning around for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Today is the best day of my life. Hands down. Easy. Best day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not every day you unearth a monumental historical event and sell it for a ton of money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That wasn't the best part. It was great, but it wasn't the peak of my day. (PAUSE) I've had a crush on you ever since I saw a picture of you on Greg's refrigerator two years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The best part of my day today is right now, sitting at this table here with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the most beautiful woman I've ever seen in my life, and you're special... and it makes me happy to be around you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me something about your family. I really don't know much about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, my family. We're what you'd probably call "not lucky". My whole family is kind of marked by tragedy, bad luck and general... shittiness. It goes back a long ways and could probably drive someone to suicide just hearing about it, so I'll keep it simple. My mom died when I was six. Cancer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And my dad got real depressed and lost his job. Out of work and with a kid to raise he had no choice but to turn to a life of crime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of crime?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was a robber. Houses mostly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Nice, mid-to-upper class home. Lots of white wood. The house is very quiet, until... the phone rings and the answer machine picks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The message ends. PAN OVER to a SOCCER MOM standing in the doorway. She drops her coffee and screams.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (on answer machine) Hi, I'm calling to let you know I'll be robbing your house today. I'll probably be there within the hour. (PAUSE) I hope you're not there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He was a very unlucky man. He spent his last days behind bars. I never really knew him. (sad moment; pause) But I guess I've also had a little luck in my life. I did have a wonderful grandmother who raised me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waiter arrives with their food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He places them down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark and Jennifer begin eating. Mark wants to say something and takes a moment to summon the courage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark didn't expect this answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jennifer thinks this over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark smiles. This is going well...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that's the end of that. Mark nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark takes a bite of his food. Jennifer smiles and does the same, oblivious to Mark's pain. Mark's cell phone rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark's face melts in terror.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, she's great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Old person's home obviously. Who wants to live with that? Gross.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I'm going to get her out of there tomorrow. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) I'm going to buy her a big beautiful mansion where she can spend her few remaining days in luxury.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what's wrong with the chef today, but these just look awful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They look fine to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're stupid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. I was thinking that since I'm going to be rich and successful now that I might be in your league. (PAUSE) And that maybe we could be together. Romantically.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would be the point?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't know, maybe we might enjoy it. Maybe we'd be good together and could have a happy life, raise a family together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I do like you. And I enjoy your company. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) And if we were to get together and procreate I would like the offspring that are carrying half my genetic code to be well taken care of and financially stable. I also think you'd make a good father and a good husband, which I like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Fantastic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unfortunately, none of that changes the fact that you'd still be contributing half of the genetic code to our children. (PAUSE) I don't want short, fat kids with little snub noses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello? (PAUSE) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (LOUDLY)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mark bursts into the hospital room to find his grandmother,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looking tired and scared, hooked up to dozens of machines, the heart monitor beeping ominously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a knock on the door. The doctor enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doctor checks Martha's chart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark sits down next to Martha, in total shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The doctor leaves. Mark holds his grandmother's hand, her hand is shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wheels in Mark's head are spinning again. Suddenly the heart monitor starts beating rapidly and Martha lurches in pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark immediately slams on the big red "call nurse" button, holding his grandmother down as she lurches in pain. Seconds later three nurses burst into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nurse #2 begins filling a syringe. Mark sits by his grandmother's head, they're both looking right at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We focus on Mark and his grandmother, inches from one another as the paramedics busy themselves around Martha's dying body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha is hanging on to every word Mark is saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tears are rolling down Martha's face as a glimmering smile overtakes her face. Mark looks up to see the nurses, paramedics and doctors all staring at Mark in total shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cardiogram flat lines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone distractedly goes back to helping the grandmother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, everyone has stopped helping Martha, they're all listening intently. Some of them are crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Martha stops breathing. The machine flatlines. And with that Martha is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark turns away from his grandmother. Standing outside in the hallway is Jennifer, watching Mark with true empathy in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Grandma, they just called me. What's going on? Are you okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, I fell on my way back to my room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do the doctors say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They say I'll probably die tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, hello. I was just coming in to check on her, you must be Martha Bellison's grandson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about she's going to die?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. It just doesn't look good. She's suffered a major heart attack and her heart is very weak, her pulse not very strong, her blood pressure is dropping rapidly and most likely she'll have a fatal heart attack during the night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yup, still going to die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, guys. I wish I felt something for you two, but I really don't. I do this exact thing about thirty times a night and it's really hardened me to human suffering. On a side note, it's fajita night at the cafeteria downstairs. You might think about grabbing a bite to eat there after your grandma dies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so scared, Mark. I don't want to die. You know, people don't talk about it much, but death is a horrible thing. One minute you're alive, there's a whole world around you, humming and jumping, people coming in and out, doors opening and closing, love and anger and the whole mess of it all, and then like that, it's all gone. (CRYING) This is it Mark, only a few hours left of this until an eternity of nothingness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grandma!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 She's seizing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm scared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen closely to me, Grandma. I have a surprise for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're wrong about what happens when you die. It's not an eternity of nothingness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you die you're going to go to your favorite place in the whole world. And you're going to be with all of the people you've ever loved and who have ever loved you. And you're going to be young again, and you'll be able to run through the fields and dance and jump, and there will be no sadness, no pain, just love and laughing and happiness. There will be ponies made of gold, and everyone will live in giant mansions, and everything will smell like cookies. And it will last for an eternity, Grandma. An eternity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Go on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What else happens?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do your jobs!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're going to be happy forever, grandma. I promise you. Say hello to my mom for me. Tell her I love her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 (TEARFULLY) I'm going to see my mother again when I die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell us more, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MARK'S CAR -- MORNING Mark and Jennifer pull up in front of Jennifer's apartment. There is a long beat of silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark nods his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so sorry, Mark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I just did something bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want to come inside?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mark and Jennifer sit side-by-side on her couch. Mark holds a can of beer in his hand, gently turning it around in his palm, staring down at it vacantly. Jennifer sadly watches Mark. Slowly and almost absentmindedly, Jennifer's hand moves over and rests gently upon Mark's wrist, settling there. We hold on them for a long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FADE UP:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark and Jennifer have fallen asleep in the exact same position, both of them sitting side-by-side no the couch, her hand still on his wrist. Mark opens his eyes and looks down at her hand, then up at Jennifer who slowly opens her eyes and smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They share a moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A bleary eyed Mark drives home from Jennifer's. As he turns onto his street he finds hundreds of cars blocking the way. A massive crowd of people are leaving their cars and walking. Mark gets out of his car to find a wild scene: hundreds of people camped out on the lawn of his apartment building. Standing by his door is the NURSE from the hospital. She immediately points at Mark and screams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark is bum-rushed by a question-asking throng. All of them are pelting Mark with questions, all of them confused and hopeful and desperately looking for answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark pushes through the crowd, overwhelmed by it all. He gets to his door and opens it, only to have the Nurse step in his path and block the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark pushes past her and into his building, closing the door behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 There he is!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Is there only one place you go when you die?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Will everyone who has ever died be there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #3 What's this place called?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #4 Will I get to have sex with people there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 You owe us an explanation. If you know something this important, you better tell us all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you people?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 The words you spoke last night, to your grandmother, spread like wildfire. Please, tell us more. Explain what you said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, fine, just give me a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mark goes to his fridge and pulls out a beer. His mind is reeling. As he opens a drawer to get a bottle opener he sees the letter: "MY INVENTION". Mark eyes it ominously. The phone rings. Mark screens the call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark walks into his bedroom and turns on the TV. Sure enough there's a newscaster on his lawn, giving a report, with a banner on the screen that reads, "New Death Discoveries".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark puts down the phone and listens to the T.V.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark puts the phone to his ear again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) (leaving message) You've been gone for twenty minutes and I turn on the T.V to see you on every station. What's going on? This is seriously the weirdest thing...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember last night when I said I think I did something bad? Well now I know I did something bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're saying that you know something different about what happens after you die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ON T.V) Twenty-four hours ago, Mark Bellison was just your typical nobody writer. (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ON T.V) (cont'd) Today, people are saying he knows new information about what happens after you die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mark, what do you know? What did you tell your grandmother last night? What's going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't explain it all right now. Why don't you come over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jennifer pushes through the throng of people, which is now even larger than before. As she reaches the door Mark opens it for her and slides her through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark hurries Jennifer into the elevator.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come up quick, they look like they could get out of hand any second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jennifer sits on the couch while Mark, agitated beyond recognition, paces the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jennifer's heart skips a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark sighs and looks out the window. The crowd extends down the block, all of them sitting calmly on his lawn, talking quietly to each other, trying to make sense of it all. Jennifer gets up and stands beside Mark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark thinks this over.
direction.name: direction

That she would be with all of the people she loved who had died and that she would live an eternity of joy and happiness.

Mark is at Lecture Films turning in the script for "The Black Plague" to Anthony. Rob gives Mark a dirty look as he passes him in the hall. Mark, smiling proudly, stands behind the camera while Nathan Goldfrappe reads his script. In the background are Jennifer and Greg, hanging out on set. Jennifer can be seen chatting with Rob by craft services. Mark removes the "For Sale" sign from the front yard of a brand new, beautiful home. Jennifer and Greg congratulate Mark enthusiastically. Mark and Jennifer are walking down the street together when Mark stops to point out a new building with a sign that reads, "A Quiet Place To Think About the Man in the Sky". The building boasts a large stained glass window portraying Mark holding the two halves of the pizza box. Mark, Jennifer and Greg laugh it up in a stretch limousine as it pulls up to the movie premier of "The Black Plague". Mark, Jennifer and Greg walk the red carpet at the premier of "The Black Plague". Mark is the center of attention. Rob stops by on the red carpet to say hello to Jennifer and whisper something into her ear. Jennifer laughs.

dialogue.raw_text: So am I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is any of it... the things you said... are they... I can't think of the word. (PAUSE) Is there a Man in the Sky?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why'd you say there was?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because I couldn't cope with the look on my grandmother's face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But how could you say something that... wasn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure. I just did it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what did you mean that I could grow old and ugly and still be beautiful to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean just that. You'll always be beautiful to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what if my looks...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It doesn't matter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel funny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me too. (PAUSE) Everything is so hard. Nothing is easy anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what I want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want short, fat kids with little snub noses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy! That's an easy one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does anyone else know about your invention?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But I'm sure it won't be long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should we tell them right away?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure. I don't think everyone will understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's going on out here? Everyone's just sitting in there. Are we gonna finish this wedding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Praise the Man in the Sky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Mark and Jennifer walk hand in hand towards the church -- and an unknowable future.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The world's last moment of honesty. A monumental occasion in the history of mankind. (PAUSE) That lowly writer who stumbled upon the ability to lie went on to become one of the most important men of his age, married to one of the most beautiful women of his time, and passed on the lying gene to generations to come. (PAUSE) A world without honesty is a world with dreams. A world with pretense. A world with fiction. A world with flattery. And most importantly, a world with true love. Put simply, a world very much like our own.
dialogue.name: dialogue
